description: From Middle English pryvy, prive, from Old French privé (“private”), from Latin prīvātus (“deprived”), perfect passive participle of prīvō (“I bereave, deprive; I free, release”). Doublet of private.

adjectives.description: privy (comparative more privy, superlative most privy)

entries.meaning: (now chiefly historical) Private, exclusive; not public; one's own. [from early 13th c.]
examples: The king retreated to his privy chamber.

entries.meaning: With knowledge of; party to; let in on. [from late 14th c.]
examples: He was privy to the discussions.

entries.meaning: An outdoor facility for urination and defecation, whether open (latrine) or enclosed (outhouse).
A lavatory: a room with a toilet.
A toilet: a fixture used for urination and defecation.
examples: Arconum—I found two chairs wanting in the gentlemen's room, and the bath room attached applied to other purposes... the privies and urinaries clean...

entries.meaning: (law) A partaker; one having an interest in an action, contract, etc. to which he is not himself a party.
